translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: , THEE Agni, have the Gods, ever of one accord, sent hither down, a God, appointed messenger, yea, with their wisdom sent thee down. The Immortal, O thou Holy One, mid mortal men, the God-devoted God, the wise, have they brought forth, brought forth the omnipresent God-devoted Sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O Agni, bring with favour to the Gods thy Brother Varuṇa who loveth sacrifice, True to the Law, the Āditya who supporteth men, the King, supporter of mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, O Friend, turn hither him who is our Friend, swift as a wheel, like two car-steeds in rapid course, Wondrous! to us in rapid course. O Agni, find thou grace for us with Varuṇa, with Maruts who illumine all. Bless us, thou Radiant One, for seed and progeny, yea, bless us, O thou Wondrous God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou who knowest Varuṇa, O Agni, put far away from us the God's displeasure. Best Sacrificer, brightest One, refulgent remove thou far from us all those who hate us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be thou, O Agni, nearest us with succour, our closest Friend while now this Morn is breaking. Reconcile to us Varuṇa, be bounteous enjoy the gracious juice; be swift to hear us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Excellent is the glance, of brightest splendour, which the auspicious God bestows on mortals- The God's glance, longed-for even as the butter, pure, heated, of the cow, the milch-cow's bounty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three are those births, the true, the most exalted, eagerly longed-for, of the God, of Agni. He came invested in the boundless region, pure, radiant, friendly, mightily resplendent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This envoy joyeth in all seats of worship, borne on his golden car, sweet-tongued Invoker: Lovely to look on, with red steeds, effulgent, like a feast rich in food, joyous for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Allied by worship, let him give man knowledge: by an extended cord they lead him onward. He stays, effectual in this mortal's dwelling, and the God wins a share in his possessions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Agni -for he knows the way- conduct us to all that he enjoys of God-sent riches, What all the Immortals have prepared with wisdom, Dyaus, Sire, Begetter, raining down true blessings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In houses first he sprang into existence, at great heaven's base, and in this region's bosom; Footless and headless, both his ends concealing, in his Bull's lair drawing himself together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wondrously first he rose aloft, defiant, in the Bull's lair, the homeof holy Order, Longed-for, young, beautiful, and far-resplendent: and sevendear frieuds sprang up unto the Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here did our human fathers take their places, fain to fulfil the sacred Law of worship. Forth drave they, with loud call, Dawn's teeming Milch-kine bid in the mountainstable, in the cavern.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Splendid were they when they had rent the mountain: others, around, shall tell forth this their exploit. They sang their song, prepared to free the cattle: they found the light; with holy hymns they worshipped.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eager, with thought intent upon the booty, the men with their celestial speech threw open, The solid mountain firm, compact, enclosing, confining Cows, the stable full of cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Milch-cow's earliest name they comprehended: they found the Mother's thrice-seven noblest titles. This the bands knew, and sent forth acclamation:with the Bull's sheen the Red One was apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The turbid darkness fled, the heaven was sp, endid! up rose the bright beam of celestial Morning. Sūrya ascended to the wide expanses, beholding deeds of men both good and evil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then, afterwards they looked around, awakened, when first they held that Heaven allotted treasure. Now all the Gods abide in all their dwellings. Varuṇa, Mitra, be the prayer effective.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I will call hither brightly-beaming Agni, the Herald, all-supporting, best at worship. He hath disclosed, like the milch cows' pure udder, the Sorria's juice when cleansed and poured from beakers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The freest God of all who should be worshipped, the guest who is received in all men's houses, Agni who hath secured the Gods’ high favour,—may he be gracious, to us Jātavedas. Next: HYMN II. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE, Faithful One, Immortal among mortals, a God among the Gods, appointed envoy, Priest, best at worship, must shine forth in glory . Agni shall be raised high with man's oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born for us here this day, O Son of Vigour, between both races of born beings, Agni, Thou farest as an envoy, having harnessed, Sublime One! thy strong-muscled radiant stallions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I laud the ruddy steeds who pour down blessing, dropping oil, flectest through the thoualit of Order. Yoking red horses to and fro thou goest between you Deities and mortal races.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa, and Indra with Viṣṇu, of the Gods, Maruts and Aśvins- These, Agni, with good car and steeds, bring hither, most bountiful, to folk with fair oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, be this our sacrifice eternal, with brave friends, rich in kine and sheep and horses, Rich, Asura! in sacred food and children, in full assembly, wealth broad-based and during.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who, sweating, brings for thee the fuel, and makes his head to ache, thy faithful servant,— Agni, to him be a self-strong Protector guard him from all who seek to do him mischief.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who brings thee food, though thou hast food in plenty, welcomes his cheerful guest and speeds him onward, Who kindles thee devoutly in his dwelling,to him be wealth secure and freely giving.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso sings praise to thee at eve or morning, and, with oblation, doth the thing thou lovest,— In his own home, even as a goId-girt courser, rescue him from distress, the bounteous giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso brings gifts to thee Immortal, Agni, and doth thee service with uplifted ladle,— Let him not, sorely toiling, lose his riches; let not the sinner's wickedness enclose him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose well-wrought worship thou acceptest, Agni, thou God a mortal's gift, thou liberal Giver,— Dear be his sacrifice to thee, Most Youthful! and may we strengthen him when he adores thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he who knows distinguish sense and folly of men, like straight and crooked backs of horses. Lead us, O God, to wealth and noble offspring: keep penury afar and grant us plenty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Sage the Sages, ne’er deceived, commanded, setting him down in dwellings of the living. Hence mayst thou, friendly God, with rapid footsteps behold the Gods, wonderful, fair to look on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Good guidance hast thou for the priest, O Agni, who, Youngest God! with outpoured Soma serves thee. Ruler of men, thou joyous God, bring treasure splendid and plentiful to aid the toiler.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now all that we, thy faithful servants, Agni, have done with feet, with hands, and with our bodies, The wise, with toil, the holy rite have guided, as those who frame a car with manual cunning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we, seven sages first in rank, engender, from Dawn the Mother, men to be ordainers. May we, Aṅgirases, be sons of Heaven, and, radiant, burst the wealth-containing mountain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As in the days of old our ancient Fathers, speeding the work of holy worship, Agni, Sought pure light and devotion, singing praises; they cleft the ground and made red Dawns apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, doing holy acts, devout, resplendent, smelting like ore their human generations. Enkindling Agni and exalting Indra, they came encompassing the stall of cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong One! he marked them-and the Gods before them-like herds of cattle in a foodful pasture. There they moaned forth their strong desire for mortals, to aid the True, the nearest One, the Living.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have worked for thee, we have laboured nobly-bright Dawns have shed their light upon our worship- Adding a beauty to the perfect Agni, and the God's beauteous eye that shines for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, Disposer, we have sung these praises to thee the Wise: do thou accept them gladly. Blaze up on high and ever make us richer. Give us great wealth, O thou whose boons are many. Next: HYMN III. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WIN, to assist you, Rudra, Lord of worship, Priest of both worlds, effectual Sacrificer, Agni, invested with his golden colours, before the thunder strike and lay you senseless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This shrine have we made ready for thy coming, as the fond dame attires her for her husband. Performer of good work, sit down before us, invested while these flames incline to meet thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hymn, O Priest, to him who hears, the gentle, to him who looks on men, exceeding gracious, A song of praise sing to the God Immortal, whom the stone, presser of the sweet juice, worships.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as true knower of the Law, O Agni, to this our solemn rite he thou attentive. When shall thy songs of festival be sung thee? When is thy friendship shown within our dwelling?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Why this complaint to Varuṇa, O Agni? And why to Heaven? for what is our transgression? How wilt thou speak to Earth and bounteous Mitra? What wilt thou say to Aryaman and Bhaga?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What, when thou blazest on the lesser altars, what to the mighty Wind who comes to bless us, True, circumambient? what to Earth, O Agni, what wilt thou say to man-destroying Rudra?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How to great Pūṣan who promotes our welfare,—to honoured Rudra what, who gives oblations? What sin of ours to the far-striding Viṣṇu, what, Agni, wilt thou tell the Lofty Arrow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What wilt thou tell the truthful band of Maruts, how answer the great Sun when thou art questioned? Before the Free, before the Swift, defend us: fulfil heaven's work, all-knowing Jātavedas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I crave the cow's true gift arranged by Order: though raw, she hath the sweet ripe juice, O Agni. Though she is black of hue with milk she teemeth, nutritious, brightly shining, all-sustaining.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni the Bull, the manly, hath been sprinkled with oil upon his back, by Law eternal. He who gives vital power goes on unswerving. Pṛśni the Bull hath milked the pure wiiite udder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By Law the Aṅgirases cleft the rock asunder, and sang their hymns together with the cattle. Bringing great bliss the men encompassed Morning: light was apparent at the birth of Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By Law the Immortal Goddesses the Waters, with meath-rich waves, O Agni, and uninjured, Like a strong courser lauded in his running, sped to flow onward swiftly and for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go never to the feast of one who harms us, the treacherous neighbour or unworthy kinsman. Punish us not for a false brother's trespass. Let us not feel the might of friend or foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, keep us safe with thy protection, loving us, honoured God! and ever guarding. Beat thou away, destroy severe affliction slay e’en the demon when he waxes mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through these our songs of praise be gracious, Agni; moved by our prayers, O Hero, touch our viands. Accept, O Aṅgiras, these our devotions, and let the praise which Gods desire address thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee who knowest, Agni, thou Disposer, all these wise secret speeches have I uttered, Sung to thee, Sage, the charming words of wisdom, to thee, O Singer, with. my thoughts and Praises. Next: HYMN IV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PUT forth like a wide-spreading net thy vigour; go like a mighty King with his attendants. Thou, following thy swift net, shootest arrows: transfix the fiends with darts that burn most fiercely.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forth go in rapid flight thy whirling weapons: follow them closely, glowing in thy fury. Spread with thy tongue the winged flames, O Agni; unfettered, cast thy firebrands all around thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send thy spies forward, fleetest in thy motion; be, ne’er deceived, the guardian of this people From him who, near or far, is bent on evil, and let no trouble sent from thee o’ercome us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rise up, O Agni, spread thee out before us: burn down our foes, thou who hast sharpened arrows. Him, blazing Agni! who hath worked us mischief, consume thou utterly like dried-up stubble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rise, Agni, drive off those who fight against us: make manifest thine own celestial vigour. Slacken the strong bows of the demon-driven: destroy our foemen whether kin or stranger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most Youthful God, he knoweth well thy favour who gave an impulse to this high devotion. All fair days and magnificence of riches hast thou beamed forth upon the good man's portals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blest, Agni, be the man, the liberal giver, who with his lauds and regular oblation Is fain to please thee for his life and dwelling. May all his days be bright: be this his longing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I praise thy gracious favour: sing in answer. May this my song sing like a loved one with thee. Lords of good steeds and cars may we adorn thee, and day by day vouchsafe thou us dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here of free choice let each one serve thee richly, resplendent day by day at eve and morning. So may we honour thee, content and joyous, passing beyond the glories of the people.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso with good steeds and fine gold, O Agni, comes nigh thee on a car laden with treasure, His Friend art thou, yea, thou art his Protector whose joy it is to entertain thee duly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through words and kinship I destroy the mighty: this power I have from Gotama my father. Mark thou this speech of ours, O thou Most Youthful, Friend of the House, exceeding wise, Invoker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Knowing no slumber, speedy and propitious, alert and ever friendly, most unwearied, May thy protecting powers, unerring Agni, taking their places here, combined, preserve us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy guardian rays, O Agni, when they saw him, preserved blind Māmateya from affliction. Lord of all riches, he preserved the pious: the fees who fain would harm them did no mischief

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee with thee may we be wealthy, may we gain strength with thee to guide us onward. Fulfil the words of both, O Ever Truthful: straightway do this, thou God whom power emboldens.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, with this fuel will we serve thee; accept the laud we sing to thee with favour Destroy the cursing Rākṣasas: preserve us, O rich in friends, from guile and scorn and slander. Next: HYMN V. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How shall we give with one accord oblation to Agni, to Vaiśvānara the Bounteous? Great light, with full high growth hath he uplifted, and, as a pillar bears the roof, sustains it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Reproach not him who, God and self-reliant, vouchsafed this bounty unto me a mortal,— Deathless, discerner, wise, to me the simple, Vaiśvānara most manly, youthful Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sharp-pointed, powerful, strong, of boundless vigour, Agni who knows the lofty hymn, kept secret As the lost milch-cow's track, the doubly Mighty,—he hath declared to me this hidden knowledge.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he with sharpened teeth, the Bounteous Giver, Agni, consume with flame most fiercely glowing. Those who regard not Varuṇa's commandments and the dear stedfast laws of sapient Mitra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like youthful women without brothers, straying, like dames who hate their lords, of evil conduct, They who are full of sin, untrue, unfaithful, they have engendered this abysmal station.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To me, weak, innocent, thou, luminous Agni, hast boldly given as ’twere a heavy burthen, This Pṛṣṭha hymn, profound and strong and mighty, of seven elements, and with offered dainties.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may our song that purifies, through wisdom reach in a moment him the Universal, Established on the height, on earth's best station, above the beauteous grassy skin of Pṛśni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of this my speech what shall I utter further? They indicate the milk stored up in secret When they have thrown as ’twere the cows' stalls open. The Bird protects earths’ best and well-loved station.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the Great Ones’ mighty apparition which from of old the radiant Cow hath followed. This, shining brightly in the place of Order, swift, hasting on in secret, she discovered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He then who shone together with his Parents remembered Pṛśni's fair and secret treasure, Which, in the Mother Cow's most lofty station, the Bull's tongue, of the flame bent forward, tasted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With reverence I declare the Law, O Agni; what is, comes by thine order, Jātavedas. Of this, whate’er it be, thou art the Sovran, yea, all the wealth that is in earth or heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is our wealth therefrom, and what our treasure? Tell us O Jātavedas, for thou knowest, What is our best course in this secret passage: we, unreproached, have reached a place far distant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is the limit, what the rules, the guerdon? Like fleet-foot coursers speed we to the contest. When will the Goddesses, the Immortal's Spouses, the Dawns, spread over us the Sun-God's splendour?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unsatisfied, with speech devoid of vigour, scanty and frivolous and inconclusive, Wherefore do they address thee here, O Agni? Let these who have no weapons suffer sorrow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The majesty of him the Good, the Mighty, aflame, hath shone for glory in the dwelling. He, clothed in light, hath shone most fair to look on, wealthy in boons, as a home shines with riches. Next: HYMN VI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRIEST of our rite, stand up erect, O Agni, in the Gods’ service best of sacrificers, For over evei y thought thou art the Ruler: thou furtherest e’en the wisdom of the pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He was set down mid men as Priest unerring, Agni, wise, welcome in our holy synods. Like Savitar he hath lifted up his splendour, and like a builder raised his smoke to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The glowing ladle, filled with oil, is lifted; choosing Gods’ service to the right he circles. Eager he rises like the new-wrought pillar which, firmly set and fixed, anoints the victims.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When sacred grass is strewn and Agni kindled, the Adhvaryu rises to, his task rejoicing. Agni the Priest, like one who tends the cattle, goes three times round, as from of old he wills it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni himself, the Priest, with measured motion, goes round, with sweet speech, cheerful, true to Order. His fulgent flames run forth like vigorous horses; all creatures are affrighted when he blazes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beautiful and auspicious is thine aspect, O lovely Agni, terrible when spreading. Thy splendours are not covered by the darkness: detraction leaves no stain upon thy body.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Naught hindered his production, Bounteous Giver: his Mother and his Sire were free to send him. Then as Friend benevolent, refulgent, Agni shone forth in human habitations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Agni, whom the twice-five sisters, dwelling together, in the homes of men engendered, Bright like a spear's tooth, wakened in the morning, with powerful mouth and like an axe well-sharpened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These thy Bay Coursers, Agni, dropping fatness, ruddy vigorous, speeding straightly forward, And red steeds, wonderful, of mighty muscle, are to this service of the Gods invited:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These brightly-shining games of thine, O Agni, that move for ever restless, all-subduing, Like falcons hasting eagerly to the quarry, roar loudly like the army of the Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, O flaming God, hath prayer been offered. Let the priest laud thee: give to him who worships. Men have established Agni as Invoker, fain to adore the glory of the living. Next: HYMN VII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HERE by ordainers was this God appointed first Invoker, best at worship, to be praised at rites: Whom Apnavāna, and the Bhṛgus caused to shine bright-coloured in the wood, spreading from home to home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When shall thy glory as a God, Agni, be suddenly shown forth. For mortal men have held thee fast, adorable in all their homes,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seeing thee faithful to the Law, most sapient, like the starry heaven, Illumining with cheerful ray each solemn rite in every house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vivasvān's envoy living men have taken as their ensign, swift, The ruler over all mankind, moving like Bhṛgu in each home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him the intelligent have they placed duly as Invoking Priest, Welcome, with sanctifying flame, best worshipper, with sevenfold might;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In his Eternal Mothers, in the wood, concealed and unapproached, Kept secret though his flames are bright seeking on all sides, quickly found.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That as food spreads forth in this earthly udder, Gods may rejoice them in the home of Order, Great Agni, served with reverence and oblation, flies ever to the sacrifice, the Faithful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bird of each rite, skilled in an envoy's duties, knowing both worlds and that which lies between them, Thou goest from of old a willing Herald, knowing full well heaven's innermost recesses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright God, thy path is black: light is before thee: thy moving splendour is the chief of wonders. When she, yet unimpregnate, hath conceived thee, even when newly born thou art an envoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yet newly born, his vigour is apparent when the wind blows upon his fiery splendour, His sharpened tongue he layeth on the brushwood, and with his teeth e’en solid food consumeth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he hath borne off food with swift flame swiftly, strong Agni makes himself a speedy envoy, Follows the rustling of the wind, consuming, and courser-like, speeds, drives the swift horse onward. Next: HYMN VIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YOUR envoy who possesses all, Immortal, bearer of your gifts, Best worshipper, I woo with song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Mighty, knows the gift of wealth, he knows the deep recess of heaven: He shall bring hitherward the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He knows, a God himself, to guide Gods to the righteous in his home: He gives e’en treasures that we love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is the Herald: well-informed, he doth his errand to and fro, Knowing the deep recess of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be they who gratify Agni with sacrificial gifts, Who cherish and enkindle him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Illustrious for wealth are they, and hero deeds, victorious, Who have served Agni reverently.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So unto us, day after day, may riches craved by many come, And power and might spring up for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That holy Singer in his strength shoots forth his arrows swifter than The swift shafts of the tribes of men. Next: HYMN IX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, show favour: great art thou who to this pious man art come, To seat thee on the sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he the Immortal, Helper, bard to be deceived among mankind, Become the messenger of all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Around the altar is he led, welcome Chief Priest at solemn rites, Or as the Potar sits him down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni in fire at sacrifice, and in the house as Lord thereof, And as a Brahman takes his seat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou comest as the guide of folk who celebrate a sacrifice, And to oblations brought by men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou servest as his messenger whose sacrifice thou lovest well, To bear the mortal's gifts to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept our solemn rite; be pleased, Aṅgiras, with our sacrifice: Give ear and listen to our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thine inviolable car, wherewith thou guardest those who give, Come near to us from every side. Next: HYMN X. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This day with praises, Agni, we bring thee that which thou lovest. Right judgment, like a horse, with our devotions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou hast ever been the Car-driver, Agni, of noble Strength, lofty sacrifice, and rightful judgment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through these our praises come thou to meet us, bright as the sunlight, O Agni, well disposed, with all thine aspects.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now may we serve thee singing these lauds this day to thee, Agni. Loud as the voice of Heaven thy blasts are roaring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Just at this time of the day and the night thy look is the sweetest: It shineth near us even as gold for glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Spotless thy body, brilliant as gold, like clarified butter: This gleams like gold on thee, O Self. dependent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All hate and mischief, yea, if committed, Agni, thou turnest, Holy One, from the man who rightly worships.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, with you Gods, prosperous be our friendships and kinships. Be this our bond here by this place, thine altar. Next: HYMN XI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THY blessed majesty, victorious Agni, shines brightly in the neighbourhood of Sūrya. Splendid to see, it shows even at nighttime, and food is fair to look on in thy beauty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, disclose his thought for him who singeth, the well, Strong God! while thou art praised with fervour. Vouchsafe to us that powerful hymn, O Mighty, which, Radiant One! with all the Gods thou lovest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From thee, O Agni, springs poetic wisdom, from thee come thoughts and hymns of praise that prosper; From thee flows wealth, with heroes to adorn it, to the true-hearted man who gives oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From thee the hero springs who wins the booty, bringer of help, mighty, of real courage. From thee comes wealth, sent by the Gods, bliss-giving; Agni, from thee the fleet impetuous charger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Immortal Agni, thee whose voice is pleasant, as first in rank, as God, religious mortals Invite with hymns; thee who removest hatred, Friend of the Home, the household's Lord, unerring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far from us thou removest want and sorrow, far from us all ill-will when thou protectest. Son of Strength, Agni, blest is he at evening, whom thou as God attendest for his welfare. Next: HYMN XII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHOSO enkindles thee, with lifted ladle, and thrice this day offers thee food, O Agni, May he excel, triumphant through thy splendours, wise through thy mental power, O Jātavedas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso with toil and trouble brings thee fuel, serving the majesty of mighty Agni, He, kindling thee at evening and at morning, prospers, and comes to wealth, and slays his foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is Master of sublime dominion, Agni is Lord of strength and lofty riches. Straightway the self-reliant God, Most Youthful, gives treasures to the mortal who adores him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most Youthful God, whatever sin, through folly, we here, as human beings, have committed, In sight of Aditi make thou us sinless remit, entirely, Agni, our offences.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even in the presence of great sin, O Agni, free us from prison of the Gods or mortals. Never may we who are thy friends be injured: grant health and strength unto our seed and offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as ye here, Gods Excellent and Holy, have loosed the cow that by the foot was tethered, So also set us free from this affliction long let our life, O Agni, be extended. Next: HYMN XIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI hath looked, benevolently-minded, on the wealth-giving spring of radiant Mornings. Come, Aśvins, to the dwelling of the pious: Sūrya the God is rising with his splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Savitar, God, hath spread on high his lustre, waving his flag like a spoil-seeking hero. Their stablished way go Varuṇa and Mitra, what time they make the Sun ascend the heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him whom they made to drive away the darkness, Lords of sure mansions, constant to their object, Him who beholds the universe, the Sun-God, seven strong and youthful Coursers carry onward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Spreading thy web with mightiest Steeds thou comest, rending apart, thou God, the black-hued mantle. The rays of Sūrya tremulously shining sink, like a hide, the darkness in the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How is it that, unbound and not supported, he falleth not although directed downward? By what self power moves he? Who hath seen it? He guards the vault of heaven, a close-set pillar. Next: HYMN XIV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE God hath looked, even Agni Jātavedas, to meet the Dawns refulgent in their glories. Come on your chariot, ye who travel widely, come to this sacrifice of ours, Nāsatyas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Producing light for all the world of creatures, God Savitar hath raised aloft his banner. Making his presence known by sunbeams, Sūrya hath filled the firmament and earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Red Dawn is come, riding with brightness onward, distinguished by her beams, gay-hued and mighty. Dawn on her nobly-harnessed car, the Goddess, awaking men to happiness, approacheth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May those most powerful steeds and chariot bring you, O Aśvins, hither at the break of morning. Here for your draught of meath are Soma juices: at this our sacrifice rejoice, ye Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How is it that, unbound and unsupported, he falleth not although directed downward? By what self-power moves he? Who hath seen it? He guards the vault of heaven, a close-set pillar? Next: HYMN XV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI the Herald, like a horse, is led forth at our solemn rite, God among Gods adorable.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three times unto our solemn rite comes Agni like a charioteer, Bearing the viands to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Round the oblations hath he paced, Agni the Wise, the Lord of Strength, Giving the offerer precious boons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who is kindled eastward for Sṛñjaya, Devāvata's son, Resplendent, tamer of the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So mighty be the Agni whom the mortal hero shall command, With sharpened teeth and bountiful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Day after day they dress him, as they clean a horse who wins the prize. Dress the red Scion of the Sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Sahadeva's princely son with two bay horses thought of me, Summoned by him I drew not back.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And truly those two noble bays I straightway took when offered me, From Sahadeva's princely son.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Long, O ye Aśvins, may he live, your care, ye Gods, the princely son. Of Sahadeva, Somaka.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cause him the youthful prince, the son of Sahadeva, to enjoy Long life, O Aśvins, O ye Gods. Next: HYMN XVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IMPETUOUS, true, let Maghavan come hither, and let his Tawny Coursers speed to reach us. For him have we pressed juice exceeding potent: here, praised with song, let him effect his visit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unyoke, as at thy journey's end, O Hero, to gladden thee today at this libation. Like Uśanā, the priest a laud shall utter, a hymn to thee, the Lord Divine, who markest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the Bull, quaffing, praises our libation, as a sage paying holy rites in secret, Seven singers here from heaven hath he begotten, who e’en by day have wrought their works while singing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When heaven's fair light by hymns was made apparent (they made great splendour shine at break of morning), He with his succour, best of Heroes, scattered the blinding darkness so that men saw clearly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, Impetuous One, hath waxed immensely: he with his vastness hath filled earth and heaven. E’en beyond this his majesty extendeth who hath exceeded all the worlds in greatness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śakra who knoweth well all human actions hath with his eager Friends let loose the waters. They with their songs cleft e’en the mountain open and willingly disclosed the stall of cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He smote away the floods' obstructer, Vṛtra; Earth, conscious, lent her aid to speed thy thunder. Thou sentest forth the waters of the ocean, as Lord through power and might, O daring Hero.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Much-invoked! the water's rock thou cleftest, Saramā showed herself and went before thee. Hymned by Aṅgirases, bursting the cow-stalls, much strength thou foundest for us as our leader.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Maghavan, Friend of Man, to aid the singer imploring thee in battle for the sunlight. Speed him with help in his inspired invokings: down sink the sorcerer, the prayerless Dasyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to our home resolved to slay the Dasyu: Kutsa longed eagerly to win thy friendship. Alike in form ye both sate in his dwelling the faithful Lady was in doubt between you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou comest, fain to succour him, with Kutsa,—a goad that masters both the Wind-God's horses, That, holding the brown steeds like spoil for capture, the sage may on the final day be present.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Kutsa, with thy thousand, thou at day-break didst hurl down greedy Śuṣṇa, foe of harvest. Quickly with Kutsa's friend destroy the Dasyus, and roll the chariot-wheel of Sūrya near us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou to the son of Vidathin, Ṛjiśvan, gavest up mighty Mṛgaya and Pipru. Thou smotest down the swarthy fifty thousand, and rentest forts as age consumes a garment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time thou settest near the Sun thy body, thy form, Immortal One, is seen expanding: Thou a wild elephant with might invested. like a dread lion as thou wieldest weapons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wishes for wealth have gone to Indra, longing for him in war for light and at libation, Eager for glory, labouring with praisesongs: he is like home, like sweet and fair nutrition.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we for you that Indra, prompt to listen, him who hath done so much for men's advantage; Who, Lord of envied bounty, to a singer like me brings quickly booty worth the capture.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the sharp-pointed arrow, O thou Hero, flieth mid any conflict of the people, When, Faithful One, the dread encounter cometh, then be thou the Protector of our body.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Further the holy thoughts of Vamadeva be thou a guileless Friend in fight for booty. We come to thee whose providence protects us: wide be thy sway for ever for thy singer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, with these men who love thee truly, free givers, Maghavan, in every battle, May we rejoice through many autumns, quelling our foes, as days subdue the nights with splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, as the Bhṛgus wrought a car, for Indra the Strong, the Mighty, we our prayer have fashioned, That he may, ne’er withdraw from us his friendship, but be our bodies' guard and strong defender.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let power swell. high like rivers for the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays, is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GREAT art thou, Indra; yea, the earth, with gladness, and heaven confess to thee thine high dominion. Thou in thy vigour having slaughtered Vṛtra didst free the floods arrested by the Dragon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Heaven trembled at the birth of thine effulgence; Earth trembled at the fear of thy displeasure. The stedfast mountains shook in agitation . the waters flowed, and desert spots were flooded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hurling his bolt with might he cleft the mountain, while, putting forth his strength, he showed his vigour. He slaughtered Vṛtra with his bolt, exulting, and, their lord slain, forth flowed the waters swiftly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy Father Dyaus esteemed himself a hero: most noble was the work of Indra's Maker, His who begat the strong bolt's Lord who roareth, immovable like earth from her foundation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who alone o’erthrows the world of creatures, Indra the peoples' King, invoked of many- Verily all rejoice in him, extolling the boons which Maghavan the God hath sent them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All Soma juices are his own for ever, most gladdening draughts are ever his, the Mighty, Thou ever wast the Treasure-Lord of treasures: Indra, thou lettest all folk share thy bounty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Moreover, when thou first wast born, O Indra, thou struckest terror into all the people. Thou, Maghavan, rentest with thy bolt the Dragon who lay against the waterfloods of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The ever-slaying, bold and furious Indra, the bright bolt's Lord, infinite, strong and mighty, Who slayeth Vṛtra and acquireth booty, giver of blessings, Maghavan the bounteous:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Alone renowned as Maghavan in battles, he frighteneth away assembled armies. He bringeth us the booty that he winneth may we, well-loved, continue in his friendship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Renowned is he when conquering and when slaying: 'fis he who winneth cattle in the combat. When Indra hardeneth his indignation all that is fixed and all that moveth fear him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath won all kine, all gold, all horses,—Maghavan, he who breaketh forts in pieces; Most manly with these men of his who help him, dealing out wealth and gathering the treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is the care of Indra for his Mother, what cares he for the Father who begat him? His care is that which speeds his might in conflicts, like wind borne onward by the clouds that thunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan makes the settled man unsettled: he scatters dust that he hath swept together, Breaking in pieces like Heaven armed with lightning: Maghavan shall enrich the man who lauds h;m.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He urged the chariot-wheel of Sūrya forward: Etaśa, speeding on his way, he rested. Him the black undulating cloud bedeweth, in this mid-air's depth, at the base of darkness,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As in the night the sacrificing priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eager for booty, craving strength and horses, we-singers stir Indra, the strong, for friendship, Who gives the wives we seek, whose succour fails not, to hasten, like a pitcher to the fountain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be thou our guardian, show thyself our kinsman, watching and blessing those who pour the Soma; As Friend, as Sire, most fatherly of fathers giving the suppliant vital strength and freedom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be helping Friend of those who seek thy friendship . give life, when lauded, Indra, to the singer. For, Indra, we the priests have paid thee worship, exalting thee with these our sacrifices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Alone, when Indra Maghavan is lauded, he slayeth many ne’er-resisted Vṛtras. Him in whose keeping is the well-loved singer never do Gods or mortals stay or hinder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: E’en so let Maghavan, the loud-voiced Indra, give us true blessings, foeless, men's upholder. King of all creatures, give us glory amply, exalted glory due to him who lauds thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let power swell high like rivers for the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays! is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XVIII. Indra and Others.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS is the ancient and accepted pathway by which all Gods have come into existence. Hereby could one be born though waxen mighty. Let him not, otherwise, destroy his Mother.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not this way go I forth: hard is the passage. Forth from the side obliquely will I issue. Much that is yet undone must I accomplish; one must I combat and the other question.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He bent his eye upon the dying Mother: My word I now withdraw. That way I follow. In Tvaṣṭar's dwelling India drank the Soma, a hundredworth of juice pressed from the mortar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What strange act shall he do, he whom his Mother bore for a thousand months and many autumns? No peer hath he among those born already, nor among those who shall be born hereafter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deeming him a reproach, his mother hid him, Indra, endowed with all heroic valour. Then up he sprang himself, assumed his vesture, and filled, as soon as born, the earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With lively motion onward flow these waters, the Holy Ones, shouting, as ’twere, together. Ask them to. tell thee what the floods are saying, what girdling rock the waters burst asunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Are they addressing him with words of welcome? Will the floods take on them the shame of Indra? With his great thunderbolt my Son hath slaughtered Vṛtra, and set these rivers free to wander.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I cast thee from me, mine,—thy youthful mother: thee, mine own offspring, Kusava hath swallowed. To him, mine infant, were the waters gracious. Indra, my Son, rose up in conquering vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art mine own, O Maghavan, whom Vyaṁsa struck to the ground and smote thy jaws in pieces. But, smitten through, the mastery thou wonnest, and with thy bolt the Dāsa's head thou crushedst.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Heifer hath brought forth the Strong, the Mighty, the unconquerable Bull, the furious Indra. The Mother left her unlicked Calf to wander, seeking himself, the path that he would follow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then to her mighty Child the Mother turned her, saying, My son, these Deities forsake thee. Then Indra said, about to slaughter Vṛtra, O my friend Vṛtra, stride full boldly forward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who was he then who made thy Mother widow? Who sought to stay thee lying still or moving? What God, when by the foot thy Sire thou tookest and slewest, was at hand to give thee comfort?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In deep distress I cooked a dog's intestines. Among the Gods I found not one to comfort. My consort I beheld in degradation. The Falcon then brought me the pleasant Soma. Next: HYMN XIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEE, verily, O Thunder-wielding Indra, all the Gods here, the Helpers swift to listen, And both the worlds elected, thee the Mighty, High, waxen strong, alone to slaughter Vṛtra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods, as worn witheld, relaxed their efforts: thou, Indra, born of truth, wast Sovran Ruler. Thou slewest Ahi who besieged the waters, and duggest out their all-supporting channels.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The insatiate one, extended, hard to waken, who slumbered in perpetual sleep, O Indra,— The Dragon stretched against the seven prone rivers, where no joint was, thou rentest with thy thunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra with might shook earth and her foundation as the wind stirs the water with its fury. Striving, with strength he burst the firm asunder, and tore away the summits of the mountains.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They ran to thee as mothers to their offspring: the clouds, like chariots, hastened forth together. Thou didst refresh the streams and force the billows: thou, Indra, settest free obstructed rivers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou for the sake of Vayya and Turvīti didst stay the great stream, flowing, all-sustaining: Yea, at their prayer didst check the rushing river and make the floods easy to cross, O Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He let the young Maids skilled in Law, unwedded, like fountains, bubbling, flow forth streaming onward. He inundated thirsty plains and deserts, and milked the dry Cows of the mighty master.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through many a morn and many a lovely autumn, having slain Vṛtra, he set free the rivers. Indra hath set at liberty to wander on earth the streams encompassed pressed together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of Bay Steeds, thou broughtest from the ant-hill the unwedded damsel's son whom ants were eating. The blind saw clearly, as he grasped the serpent, rose, brake the jar: his joints again united.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To the wise man, O Sage and Sovran Ruler, the man who knoweth all thine ancient exploits. Hath told these deeds of might as thou hast wrought them, great acts, spontaneous, and to man's advantage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let powers swell high, like rivers, for the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays! is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FROM near or far away may mighty Indra giver of succour, come for our protection Lord of men, armed with thunder, with the Strongest, slaying his foes in conflict, in the battles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra come to us with Tawny Coursers, inclined to us, to favour and enrich us. May Maghavan, loud-voiced and wielding thunder, stand by us at this sacrifice, in combat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, honouring this our sacrifice, O Indra, shalt give us strength and fill us full of courage. To win the booty, Thunder-armed! like hunters may we with thee subdue in fight our foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loving us well, benevolent, close beside us, drink, Godlike Indra, of the well-pressed Soma. Drink of the meath we offer, and delight thee with food that cometh from the mountain ridges.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who is sung aloud by recent sages, like a ripe-fruited tree, a scythe-armed victor,— I, like a bridegroom thinking of his consort, call hither Indra, him invoked of many;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who in native strength is like a mountain, the lofty Indra born or old for conquest, Terrific wielder of the ancient thunder. filled full with splendour as a jar with water.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom from of old there is not one to hinder, none to curtail the riches of his bounty. Pouring forth freely, O thou Strong and Mighty, vouchsafe us riches, God invoked of many!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of wealth and homes of men thou art the ruler, and opener of the stable of the cattle. Helper of men, winner of spoil in combats, thou leadest to an ample heap of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By what great might is he renowned as strongest, wherewith the Lofty One stirs up wild battles? Best soother of the worshipper's great sorrow, he gives possessions to the man who lauds him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay us not; bring, bestow onus the ample gift which thou hast to give to him who offers. At this new gift, with this laud sung before thee, extolling thee, we, Indra, will declare it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let power swell high, like rivers, for the singer. A new hymn, Lord of Bays! for thee is fashioned. May we, car-born, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY Indra come to us for our protection; here be the Hero, praised, our feast-companion. May he whose powers are many, waxen mighty, cherish, like Dyaus, his own supreme dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here magnify his great heroic exploits, most glorious One, enriching men with bounties, Whose will is like a Sovran in assembly, who rules the people, Conqueror, all-surpassing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither let Indra come from earth or heaven, hither with speech from firmament or ocean; With Maruts, from the realm of light to aid us, or from a distance, from the seat of Order.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Indra will we laud in our assemblies, him who is Lord of great and lasting riches, Victor with Vāyu where the herds are gathered, who leads with boldness on to higher fortune.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Priest, Lord of many blessings, striving,—who fixing reverence on reverence, giving Vent to his voice, inciteth men to worship—with lauds bring Indra hither to our dwellings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When sitting pondering in deep devotion in Auśija's abode they ply the press-stone, May he whose wrath is fierce, the mighty bearer, come as the house-lord's priest within our chambers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Surely the power of Bhārvara the mighty for ever helpeth to support the singer; That which in Auśija's abode lies hidden, to come forth for delight and for devotion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he unbars the spaces of the mountains, and quickens with his floods the water-torrents, He finds in lair the buffalo and wild-ox when the wise lead him on to vigorous exploit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Auspicious are thy hands, thine arms well-fashioned which proffer bounty, Indra, to thy praiser. What sloth is this? Why dost thou not rejoice thee? Why dost thou not delight thyself with giving?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So Indra is the truthful Lord of treasure. Freedom he gave to man by slaying Vṛtra. Much-lauded! help us with thy power to riches: may I be sharer of thy Godlike favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let power swell high, like rivers, for the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays! is fashioned. May we, care-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THAT gift of ours which Indra loves and welcomes, even that he makes for us, the Great and Strong One. He who comes wielding in his might the thunder, Maghavan, gives prayer, praise, and laud, and Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bull, hurler of the four-edged rain-producer with both his arms, strong, mighty, most heroic; Wearing as wool Paruṣṇī for adornment, whose joints for sake of friendship he hath covered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: God who of all the Gods was born divinest, endowed with ample strength and mighty powers, And bearing in his arms the yearning thunder, with violent rush caused heaven and earth to tremble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before the High God, at his birth, heaven trembled, earth, many floods and all the precipices. The Strong One bringeth nigh the Bull's two Parents: loud sing the winds, like men, in air's mid-region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These are thy great deeds, Indra, thine, the Mighty, deeds to be told aloud at all libations, That thou, O Hero, bold and boldly daring, didst with thy bolt, by strength, destroy the Dragon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True are all these thy deeds, O Most Heroic. The Milch-kine issued from the streaming udder. In fear of thee, O thou of manly spirit, the rivers swiftly set themselves in motion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With joy, O Indra, Lord of Tawny Coursers, the Sisters then, these Goddesses, extolled thee, When thou didst give the prisoned ones their freedom to wander at their will in long succession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed is the gladdening stalk as ’twere a river: so let the rite, the toiler's power, attract thee To us-ward, of the Bright One, as the courser strains his. exceedingly strong leather bridle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ever by us perform thy most heroic, thine highest, best victorious deeds, O Victor. For us make Vṛtras easy to be conquered: destroy the weapon of our mortal foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Graciously listen to our prayer, O Indra, and strength of varied sort bestow thou on us. Send to us all intelligence arid wisdom O Maghavan, be he who gives us cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let wealth swell high like rivers to the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays, is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How, what priest's sacrifice hath he made mighty, rejoicing in the Soma and its fountain? Delighting in juice, eagerly drinking, the Lofty One hath waxed for splendid riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What hero hath been made his feast-companion? Who hath been partner in his loving-kindness? What know we of his wondrous acts? How often comes he to aid and speed the pious toiler?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How heareth Indra offered invocation? How, hearing, marketh he the invoker's wishes? What are his ancient acts of bounty? Wherefore call they him One who filleth full the singer?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How doth the priest who laboureth, ever longing, win for himself the wealth which he possesseth? May he, the God, mark well my truthful praises, having received the homage which he loveth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How, and what bond of friendship with a mortal hath the God chosen as this morn is breaking? How, and what love hath he for those who love him, who have entwined in him their firm affection?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Is then thy friendship with thy friends most mighty? Thy brotherhood with us,—when may we tell it? The streams of milk move, as most wondrous sunlight, the beauty of the Lovely One for glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: About to stay the Indra-less destructive spirit he sharpens his keen arms to strike her. Whereby the Strong, although our debts’ exactor, drives in the distant mornings that we know not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eternal Law hath varied food that strengthens; thought of eternal Law, removes transgressions. The praise-hymn of eternal Law, arousing, glowing, hath oped the deaf ears of the living.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Firm-seated are eternal Law's foundations in its fair form are many splendid beauties. By holy Law long lasting food they bring us; by holy Law have cows come to our worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fixing eternal Law he, too, upholds it swift moves the might of Law and wins the booty. To Law belong the vast deep Earth and Heaven: Milch-kine supreme, to Law their milk they render.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded,—glorified with praises, let power swell high like rivers to the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays, is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT worthy praise will bring before us Indra, the Son of Strength, that he may grant us riches; For he the Hero, gives the singer treasures: he is the Lord who sends us gifts, ye people.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To be invoked and hymned in fight with Vṛtra, that well-praised Indra gives us real bounties. That Maghavan brings comfort in the foray to the religious man who pours libations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, verily, the men invoke in combat; risking their lives they make him their protector, When heroes, foe to foe, give up their bodies, fighting, each side, for children and their offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong God! the folk at need put forth their vigour, striving together in the whirl of battle. When warrior bands encounter one another some in the grapple quit themselves like Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hence many a one worships the might of Indra: hence let the brew succeed the meal-oblation. Hence let the Soma banish those who pour not: even hence I joy to pay the Strong One worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra gives comfort to the man who truly presses, for him who longs for it, the Soma, Not disaffected, with devoted spirit this man he takes to be his friend in battles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who this day for Indra presses Soma, prepares the brew and fries the grains of barley— Loving the hymns of that devoted servant, to him may Indra give heroic vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the impetuous chief hath sought the conflict , and the lord looked upon the long-drawn battle, The matron calls to the Strong God whom pressers of Soma have encouraged in the dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He bid a small price for a thing of value: I was content, returning, still unpurchased. He heightened not his insufficient offer. Simple and clever, both milk out the udder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who for ten milch-kine purchaseth from me this Indra who is mine? When he hath slain the Vṛtras let the buyer give him back to me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Indra! lauded, glorified with praises, let wealth swell high like rivers for the singer. For thee a new hymn, Lord of Bays, is fashioned. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever. Next: HYMN XXV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT friend of man, God-loving, hath delighted, yearning therefor, this day in Indra's friendship? Who with enkindled flame and flowing Soma laudeth him for his great protecting favour?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who hath with prayer bowed to the Soma-lover? What pious man endues the beams of morning? Who seeks bond, friendship, brotherhood with Indra? Who hath recourse unto the Sage for succour?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who claims to-day the Deities' protection, asks Aditi for light, or the Ādityas? Of whose pressed stalk of Soma drink the Aśvins, Indra, and Agni, well-inclined in spirit?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him shall Agni Bhārata give shelter: long shall he look upon the Sun up-rising, Who sayeth, Let us press the juice for Indra, man's Friend, the Hero manliest of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him neither few men overcome, nor many to him shall Aditi give spacious shelter. Dear is the pious, the devout, to Indra dear is the zealous, dear the Soma-bringer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Hero curbs the mighty for the zealous: the presser's brew Indra possesses solely: No brother, kin, or friend to him who pours not, destroyer of the dumb who would resist him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not with the wealthy churl who pours no Soma doth Indra, Soma-drinker, bind alliance. He draws away his wealth and slays him naked, own Friend to him who offers, for oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Highest and lowest, men who stand between diem, going, returning, dwelling in contentment, Those who show forth their strength when urged to battle-these are the men who call for aid on Indra. Next: HYMN XXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I WAS aforetime Manu, I was Sūrya: I am the sage Kakṣīvān, holy singer. Kutsa the son of Ārjuni I master. I am the sapient Uśanā behold me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I have bestowed the earth upon the Ārya, and rain upon the man who brings oblation. I guided forth the loudly-roaring waters, and the Gods moved according to my pleasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the wild joy of Soma I demolished Śambara's forts, ninety-and-nine, together; And, utterly, the hundredth habitation, when helping Divodāsa Atithigva.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before all birds be ranked this Bird, O Maruts; supreme of falcons be this fleet-winged Falcon, Because, strong- pinioned, with no car to bear him, he brought to Manu the Godloved oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the Bird brought it, hence in rapid motion sent on the wide path fleet as thought he hurried. Swift he returned with sweetness of the Soma, and hence the Falcon hath acquired his glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearing the stalk, the Falcon speeding onward, Bird bringing from afar the draught that gladdens, Friend of the Gods, brought, grasping fast, the Soma which be bad taken from yon loftiest heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Falcon took and brought the Soma, bearing thousand libations with him, yea, ten thousand. The Bold One left Malignities behind him, wise, in wild joy of Soma, left the foolish. Next: HYMN XXVII. The Falcon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I, As I lay within the womb, considered all generations of these Gods in order. A hundred iron fortresses confined me but forth I flew with rapid speed a Falcon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not at his own free pleasure did he bear me: he conquered with his strength and manly courage. Straightway the Bold One left the fiends behind him and passed the winds as he grew yet more mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When with loud cry from heaven down sped the Falcon, thence hasting like the wind he bore the Bold One. Then, wildly raging in his mind, the archer Kṛśānu aimed and loosed the string to strike him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Falcon bore him from heaven's lofty summit as the swift car of Indra's Friend bore Bhujyu. Then downward hither fell a flying feather of the Bird hasting forward in his journey.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And now let Maghavan accept the beaker, white, filled with milk, filled with the shining liquid; The best of sweet meath which the priests have offered: that Indra to his joy may drink, the Hero, that he may take and drink it to his rapture. Next: HYMN XXVIII. Indra-Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ALLIED with thee, in this thy friendship, Soma, Indra for man made waters flow together, Slew Ahi, and sent forth the Seven Rivers, and opened as it were obstructed fountains.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, with thee for his confederate, Indra swiftly with might pressed down the wheel of Sūrya. What rolled, all life's support, on heaven's high summit was separated from the great oppressor.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra smote down, Agni consumed, O Indu, the Dasyus ere the noontide in the conflict. Of those who gladly sought a hard-won dwelling he cast down many a thousand with his arrow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lower than all besides hast thou, O Indra, cast down the Dasyus, abject tribes of Dāsas. Ye drave away, ye put to death the foemen, and took great vengeance with your murdering weapons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, of a truth, Indra and Soma, Heroes, ye burst the stable of the kine and horses, The stable which the bar or stone obstructed; and piercing through set free the habitations. Next: HYMN XXIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME, lauded, unto us with powers and succours, O Indra, with thy Tawny Steeds; exulting, Past even the foeman's manifold libations, glorified with our hymns, true Wealth-bestower.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Man's Friend, to this our sacrifice he cometh marking how he is called by Soma-pressers. Fearless, and conscious that his Steeds are noble, he joyeth with the Soma-pouring heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make his cars hear, that he may show his vigour and may be joyful in the way he loveth. May mighty Indra pouring forth in bounty bestow on us good roads and perfect safety;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who with succour comes to his implorer, the singer here who with his song invites him; He who himself sets to the pole swift Coursers, he who hath hundreds, thousands, Thunder-wielder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra Maghavan, by thee protected may we be thine, princes and priests and singers, Sharing the riches sent from lofty heaven which yields much food, and all desire its bounty. Next: HYMN XXX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O INDRA, Vṛtra-slayer, none is better, mightier than thou: Verily there is none like thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like chariot-wheels these people all together follow after thee: Thou ever art renowned as Great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not even all the gathered Gods conquered thee, Indra, in the war, When thou didst lengthen days by night.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When for the sake of those oppressed, and Kutsa as he battled, Thou stolest away the Sun's car-wheel.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, fighting singly, Indra. thou o’ercamest all the furious Gods, thou slewest those who strove with thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When also for a mortal man, Indra, thou speddest forth the Sun, And holpest Etaśa with might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What? Vṛtra-slayer, art not thou, Maghavan, fiercest in thy wrath? So hast thou quelled the demon too.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And this heroic deed of might thou, Indra, also hast achieved, That thou didst smite to death the Dame, Heaven's Daughter, meditating ill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, Mighty One, didst crush Uṣas, though Daughter of the Sky. When lifting up herself in pride.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then from her chariot Uṣas fled, affrighted, from her ruined car. When the strong God had shattered it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So there this car of Uṣas lay, broken to pieces, in Vipāś, And she herself fled far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, didst. with magic power resist the overflowing stream Who spread her waters o’er the land.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Valiantly didst thou seize and take the store which Śuṣṇa had amassed, When thou didst crush his fortresses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, also smotest down Kulitara's son Śambara, The Dāsa, from the lofty hill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of Dāsa Varcin's thou didst slay the hundred thousand and the five, Crushed like the fellies, of a car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So Indra, Lord of Heroes, Powers, caused the unwedded damsel's son, The castaway, to share the lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So sapient Indra, Lord of Might, brought Turvaśa and Yadu, those Who feared the flood, in safety o’er.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Arṇa and Citraratha, both Āryas, thou, Indra, slewest swift, On yonder side of Sarayu,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Vṛtra-slayer, didst conduct those two forlorn, the blind, the lame. None may attain this bliss of thine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Divodāsa, him who brought oblations, Indra overthrew A hundred fortresses of stone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The thirty thousand Dāsas he with magic power and weapons sent To slumber, for Dabhīti's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O Vṛtra-slayer, thou art general Lord of kine for all, Thou Shaker of all things that be.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, whatever deed of might thou hast this day to execute, None be there now to hinder it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Watchful One, may Aryaman the God give thee all goodly things. May Pūṣan, Bhaga, and the God Karūḷatī give all things fair. Next: HYMN XXXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH what help will he come to us, wonderful, ever-waxing Friend; With what most mighty company?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What genuine and most liberal draught will spirit thee with juice to burst Open e’en strongly-guarded wealth?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou who art Protector of us thy friends who praise thee With hundred aids approach us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as a courser's circling wheel, so turn thee hitherward to us, Attracted by the hymns of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou seekest as it were thine own stations with swift descent of powers: I share thee even with the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time thy courage and his wheels together, Indra, run their course With thee and with the Sun alike,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So even, Lord of Power and Might, the people call thee Maghavan, Giver, who pauses not to think.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And verily to him who toils and presses Soma juice for thee Thou quickly givest ample wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No, not a hundred hinderers can check thy gracious bounty's flow, Nor thy great deeds when thou wilt act.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thine assistance keep us safe, thy hundred and thy thousand aids: May all thy favours strengthen us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou elect us this place for friendship and prosperity, And great celestial opulence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Favour us, Indra, evermore with overflowing store of wealth: With all thy succours aid thou us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With new protections, Indra, like an archer, open thou for us The stables that are filled with kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our chariot, Indra, boldly moves endued with splendour, ne’er repulsed, Winning for us both kine and steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Sūrya, make our fame to be most excellent among the Gods, Most lofty as the heaven on high. Next: HYMN XXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O THOU who slewest Vṛtra, come, O Indra, hither to our side, Mighty One with thy mighty aids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Swift and impetuous art thou, wondrous amid the well-dressed folk: Thou doest marvels for our help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even with the weak thou smitest down him who is stronger, with thy strength The mighty, with the Friends thou hast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, we are close to thee; to thee we sing aloud our songs: Help and defend us, even us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O Caster of the Stone, come with thy succours wonderful, Blameless, and irresistible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be friends of one like thee, O Indra, with the wealth of kine, Comrades for lively energy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Indra, art alone the Lord of strength that comes from kine So grant thou us abundant food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They turn thee not another way, when, lauded, Lover of the Song, Thou wilt give wealth to those who praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gotamas have sung their song of praise to thee that thou mayst give, Indra, for lively energy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will declare thy hero deeds, what Dāsa forts thou brakest down, Attacking them in rapturous joy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sages sing those manly deeds which, Indra, Lover of the Song, Thou wroughtest when the Soma flowed.
