translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the Gotamas who bring thee praises have grown strong by thee. Give them renown with hero sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Indra, verily thou art the general treasure even of all . Thee, therefore, do we invocate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Excellent Indra, turn to us: glad thee among us with the juice Of Somas, Soma-drinker thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May praise from us who think Qn thee, O Indra, bring thee near to us. Turn thy two Bay Steeds hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eat of our sacrificial cake: rejoice thee in the songs we sing. Even as a lover in his bride.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To India for a thousand steeds well-trained and fleet of foot we pray, And hundred jars of Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We make a hundred of thy kine, yea, and a thousand, hasten nigh: So let thy bounty come to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have obtained, a gift from thee, ten water-ewers wrought of gold: Thou, Vṛtra-slayer, givest much.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A bounteous Giver, give us much, bring much and not a trifling gift: Much, Indra, wilt thou fain bestow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vṛtra-slayer, thou art famed in many a place as bountiful Hero, thy bounty let us share.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I praise thy pair of Tawny Steeds, wise Son of him who giveth kine Terrify not the cows with these.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like two slight images of girls, unrobed, upon a new-wrought post, So shine the Bay Steeds in their course.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For me the Bays are ready when I start, or start not, with the dawn, Innocuous in the ways they take. Next: HYMN XXXIII. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I SEND my voice as herald to the Ṛbhus; I crave the white cow for the overspreading. Wind-sped, the Skillful Ones in rapid motion have in an instant compassed round the heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Rbus had with care and marvels done proper service to assist their Parents, They won the friendship of the Gods; the Sages carried away the fruit of their devotion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they who made their Parents, who were lying like posts that moulder, young again for ever,— May Vāja, Vibhvan, Ṛbhu, joined with Indra , protect our sacrifice, the Soma-lovers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As for a year the Ṛbhus kept the Milch-cow, throughout a year fashioned and formed her body, And through a year's space still sustained her brightness, through these their labours they were made immortal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Two beakers let us make,—thus said the eldest. Let us make three,—this was the younger's sentence. Four beakers let us make,—thus spoke the youngest. Tvaṣṭar approved this rede of yours, O Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men spake truth and even so they acted: this Godlike way of theirs the Ṛbhus followed. And Tvaṣṭar, when he looked on the four beakers resplendent as the day, was moved with envy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When for twelve days the Ṛbhus joyed reposing as guests of him who never may be hidden, They made fair fertile fields, they brought the rivers. Plants spread o’er deserts, waters filled the hollows.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they who formed the swift car, bearing Heroes, and the Cow omniform and all-impelling, Even may they form wealth for us,—the Ṛbhus, dexterous-handed, deft in work and gracious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So in their work the Gods had satisfaction, pondering it with thought and mental insight. The Gods’ expert artificer was Vāja, Indra's Ṛbhukṣan, Varuṇa's was Vibhvan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who made glad with sacrifice and praises, wrought the two Bays, his docile Steeds, for Indra,— Ṛbhus, as those who wish a friend to prosper, bestow upon us gear and growth of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This day have they set gladdening drink before you. Not without toil are Gods inclined to friendship. Therefore do ye who are so great, O Ṛbhus, vouchsafe us treasures at this third libation. Next: HYMN XXXIV. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this our sacrifice come Ṛbhu, Vibhvan, Vāja, and Indra with the gift of riches, Because this day hath Dhiṣaṇā the Goddess set drink for you: the gladdening draughts have reached you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Knowing your birth and rich in gathered treasure, Ṛbhus, rejoice together with the Ṛtus. The gladdening draughts and wisdom have approached you: send ye us riches with good store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For you was made this sacrifice, O Ṛbhus, which ye, like men, won for yourselves aforetime. To you come all who find in you their pleasure: ye all were—even the two elder—Vājas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now for the mortal worshipper, O Heroes, for him who served you, was the gift of riches. Drink, Vājas, Ṛbhus! unto you is offered, to gladden you, the third and great libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, Heroes, Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans, glorified for the sake of mighty treasure. These draughts approach you as the day is closing, as cows, whose calves are newly-born, their stable.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to this sacrifice of ours, ye Children of Strength, invoked with humble adoration. Drink of this meath, Wealth-givers, joined with Indra with whom ye are in full accord, ye Princes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Close knit with Varuṇa drink the Soma, Indra; close-knit, Hymn-lover! with the Maruts drink it: Close-knit with drinkers first, who drink in season; close-knit with heavenly Dames who give us treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoice in full accord with the Ādityas, in concord with the Parvatas, O Ṛbhus; In full accord with Savitar, Divine One; in full accord with floods that pour forth riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ṛbhus, who helped their Parents and the Aśvins, who formed the Milch-cow and the pair of horses, Made armour, set the heaven and earth asunder,—far- reaching Heroes, they have made good offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who have wealth in cattle and in booty, in heroes, in rich sustenance and treasure, Such, O ye Ṛbhus, first to drink, rejoicing, give unto us and those who laud our present.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye were not far: we have not left you thirsting, blameless in this our sacrifice, O Ṛbhus. Rejoice you with the Maruts and with Indra, with the Kings, Gods! that ye may give us riches. Next: HYMN XXXV. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, O ye Sons of Strength, ye Ṛbhus; stay not afar, ye Children of Sudhanvan. At this libation is your gift of treasure. Let gladdening draughts approach you after Indra's.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither is come the Ṛbhus' gift of riches; here was the drinking of the well-pressed Soma, Since by dexterity and skill as craftsmen ye made the single chalice to be fourfold

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye made fourfold the chalice that wag single: ye spake these words and said, O Friend, assist us; Then, Vājas! gained the path of life eternal, deft-handed Ṛbhus, to the Gods’ assembly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Out of what substance was that chalice fashioned which ye made fourfold by your art and wisdom? Now for the gladdening draught press out the liquor, and drink, O Ṛbhus, of die meath of Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye with your cunning made your Parents youthful; the cup, for Gods to drink, ye formed with cunning; With cunning, Ṛbhus, rich in treasure, fashioned the two swift Tawny Steeds who carry Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso pours out for you, when days are closing, the sharp libation for your joy, O Vājas, For him, O mighty Ṛbhus, ye, rejoicing, have fashioned wealth with plenteous store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of Bay Steeds, at dawn the juice thou drankest: thine, only thine, is the noonday libation. Now drink thou with the wealth-bestowing Ṛbhus, whom for their skill thou madest friends, O Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye, whom your artist skill hath raised to Godhead have set you down above in heaven like falcons. So give us riches, Children of Sudhanvan, O Sons of Strength; ye have become immortal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The third libation, that bestoweth treasure, which ye have won by skill, ye dexterous-handed,— This drink hath been effused for you, O Ṛbhus . drink it with high delight, with joy like Indra's. Next: HYMN XXXVI. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE car that was not made for horses or for reins, three-wheeled, worthy of lauds, rolls round the firmament. That is the great announcement of your Deity, that, O ye Ṛbhus, ye sustain the earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Sapient Ones who made the lightly-rolling car out of your mind, by thought, the car that never errs, You, being such, to drink of this drink-offering, you, O ye Vājas, and ye Ṛbhus, we invoke.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vājas, Ṛbhus, reaching far, among the Gods this was your exaltation gloriously declared, In that your aged Parents, worn with length of days, ye wrought again to youth so that they moved at will.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The chalice that wag single ye have made fourfold, and by your wisdom brought the Cow forth from the hide. So quickly, mid the Gods, ye gained immortal life. Vājas and Ṛbhus, your great work must be extolled.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wealth from the Ṛbhus is most glorious in renown, that which the Heroes, famed for vigour, have produced. In synods must be sung the car which Vibhvan wrought: that which ye favour, Gods! is famed among mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong is the steed, the man a sage in eloquence, the bowman is a hero hard to beat in fight, Great store of wealth and manly power hath he obtained whom Vāja, Vibhvan, Ṛbhus have looked kindly on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you hath been assigned the fairest ornament, the hymn of praise: Vājas and Ṛbhus, joy therein; For ye have lore and wisdom and poetic skill: as such, with this our prayer we call on you to come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: According to the wishes of our hearts may ye, who have full knowledge of all the delights of men, Fashion for us, O Ṛbhus, power and splendid wealth, rich in high courage, excellent, and vital strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bestowing on us here riches and offspring, here fashion fame for us befitting heroes. Vouchsafe us wealth of splendid sort, O Ṛbhus, that we may make us more renowned than others. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME to our sacrifice, Vājas, Ṛbhukṣans, Gods, by the paths which Gods are wont to travel, As ye, gay Gods, accept in splendid weather the sacrifice among these folk of Manus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these rites please you in your heart and spirit; may the drops clothed in oil this day approach you. May the abundant juices bear you onward to power and strength, and, when imbibed, delight you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your threefold going near is God-appointed, so praise is given you, Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans. So, Manus-like, mid younger folk I offer, to you who are aloft in heaven, the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong, with fair chains of gold and jaws of iron, ye have a splendid car and well-fed horses. Ye Sons of Strength, ye progeny of Indra, to you the best is offered to delight you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ṛbhukṣans! him, for handy wealth, the mightiest comrade in the fight, Him, Indra's equal, we invoke, most bounteous ever, rich in steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal man whom, Ṛbhus, ye and Indra favour with your help, Must be successful, by his thoughts, at sacrifice and with the steed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans, free for us the paths to sacrifice, Ye Princes, lauded, that we may press forward to each point of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans, ye Nāsatyas, Indra, bless this wealth, And, before other men's, the steed, that ample riches may be won. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Dadhikris.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FROM you two came the gifts in days aforetime which Trasadasyu granted to the Pūrus. Ye gave the winner of our fields and plough-lands, and the strong smiter who subdued the Dasyus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And ye gave mighty Dadhikrās, the giver of many gifts, who visiteth all people, Impetuous hawk, swift and of varied colour, like a brave King whom each true man must honour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, as ’twere down a precipice, swift rushing, each Pūru praises and his heart rejoices,— Springing forth like a hero fain for battle, whirling the car and flying like the tempest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who gaineth precious booty in the combats and moveth, winning spoil, among the cattle; Shown in bright colour, looking on the assemblies, beyond the churl, to worship of the living.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loudly the folk cry after him in battles, as ’twere a thief who steals away a garment; Speeding to glory, or a herd of cattle, even as a hungry falcon swooping downward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, fain to come forth first amid these armies, this way and that with rows of cars he rushes, Gay like a bridesman, making him a garland, tossing the dust, champing the rein that holds him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And that strong Steed, victorious and faithful, obedient with his body in the combat, Speeding straight on amid the swiftly pressing, casts o’er his brows the dust he tosses upward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And at his thunder, like the roar of heaven, those who attack tremble and are affrighted; For when he fights against embattled thousands, dread is he in his striving; none may stay him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The people praise the overpowering swiftness of this fleet Steed who giveth men abundance. Of him they say when drawing back from battle. Dadhikrās hath sped forward with his thousands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dadhikrās hath o’erspread the Fivefold People with vigour, as the Sun lightens the waters. May the strong Steed who winneth hundreds, thousands, requite with sweetness these my words and praises. Next: HYMN XXXIX Dadhikrās.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now give we praise to Dadhikrās the rapid, and mention in our laud the Earth and Heaven. May the Dawns flushing move me to exertion, and bear me safely over every trouble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I praise the mighty Steed who fills my spirit, the Stallion Dadhikrāvan rich in bounties, Whom, swift of foot and shining bright as Agni, ye, Varuṇa and Mitra, gave to Pūrus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who hath honoured, when the flame is kindled at break of dawn, the Courser Dadhikrāvan, Him, of one mind with Varuṇa and Mitra may Aditi make free from all transgression.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When we remember mighty Dadhikrāvan our food and strength, then the blest name of Maruts, Varuṇa, Mitra, we invoke for welfare, and Agni, and the thunder-wielding Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both sides invoke him as they call on Indra when they stir forth and turn to sacrificing. To us have Varuṇa and Mitra granted the Courser Dadhikrās, a guide for mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So have I glorified with praise strong Dadhikrāvan, conquering Steed. Sweet may he make our mouths; may he prolong the days we have to live. Next: HYMN XL. Dadhikrāvan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET us recite the praise of Dadhikrāvan: may all the Mornings move me to exertion; Praise of the Lord of Waters, Dawn, and Agni, Bṛhaspati Son of Aṅgiras, and Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brave, seeking war and booty, dwelling with the good and with the swift, may he hasten the food of Dawn. May he the true, the fleet, the lover of the course, the bird-like Dadhikrāvan, bring food, strength, and light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His pinion, rapid runner, fans him m his way, as of a bird that hastens onward to its aim, And, as it were a falcon's gliding through the air, strikes Dadhikrāvan's side as he speeds on with might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bound by the neck and by the flanks and by the mouth, the vigorous Courser lends new swiftness to his speed. Drawing himself together, as his strength allows, Dadhikrās springs along the windings of the paths.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Haṁsa homed in light, the Vasu in mid-air, the priest beside the altar, in the house the guest, Dweller in noblest place, mid men, in truth, in sky, born of flood, kine, truth, mountain, he is holy Law. Next: HYMN XLI. Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHAT laud, O Indra-Varuṇa, with oblation, hath like the Immortal Priest obtained your favour? Hath our effectual laud, addressed with homage, touched you, O Indra-Varuṇa, in spirit?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who with dainty food hath won you, Indra and Varuṇa, Gods, as his allies to friendship, Slayeth the Vṛtras and his foes in battles, and through your mighty favours is made famous.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Varuṇa are most liberal givers of treasure to the men who toil to serve them, When they, as Friends inclined to friendship, honoured with dainty food, delight in flowing Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Varuṇa, ye hurl, O Mighty, on him your strongest flashing bolt of thunder Who treats us ill, the robber and oppressor: measure on him your overwhelming vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, be ye the lovers of this my song, as steers who love the milch-Cow. Milk may it yield us as, gone forth to pasture, the great Cow pouring out her thousand rivers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For fertile fields, for worthy sons and grandsons, for the Sun's beauty and for steer-like vigour, May Indra-Varuṇa with gracious favours work marvels for us in the stress of battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For you, as Princes, for your ancient kindness, good comrades of the man who seeks for booty, We choose to us for the dear bond of friendship, most liberal Heroes bringing bliss like parents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Showing their strength, these hymns for grace, Free-givers I have gone to you, devoted, as to battle. For glory have they gone, as milk to Soma, to Indra-Varuṇa my thoughts and praises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra and to Varuṇa, desirous of gaining wealth have these my thoughts proceeded. They have come nigh to you as treasure-lovers, like mares, fleet-footed, eager for the glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we ourselves be lords of during riches, of ample sustenance for car and hones. So may the Twain who work with newest succours bring yoked teams hitherward to us and riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with your mighty succours, O ye Mighty; come, Indra-Varuṇa, to us in battle. What time the flashing arrows play in combat, may we through you be winners in the contest. Next: HYMN XLIL Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I AM the royal Ruler, mine is empire, as mine who sway all life are all Immortals. Varuṇa's will the Gods obey and follow. I am the King of men's most lofty cover.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I am King Varuṇa. To me were given these first existing high celestial powers. Varuṇa's will the Gods obey and follow. I am the King of men's most lofty cover.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I Varuṇa am Indra: in their greatness, these the two wide deep fairly-fashioned regions, These the two world-halves have I, even as Tvaṣṭar knowing all beings, joined and held together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I made to flow the moisture-shedding waters, and set the heaven firm in the scat of Order. By Law the Son of Aditi, Law Observer, hath spread abroad the world in threefold measure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Heroes with noble horses, fain for battle, selected warriors, call on me in combat. I Indra Maghavan, excite the conflict; I stir the dust, Lord of surpassing vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All this I did. The Gods’ own conquering power never impedeth me whom none opposeth. When lauds and Soma juice have made me joyful, both the unbounded regions are affrighted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All beings know these deeds of thine thou tellest this unto Varuṇa, thou great Disposer! Thou art renowned as having slain the Vṛtras. Thou madest flow the floods that were obstructed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our fathers then were these, the Seven his, what time the son of Durgaha was captive. For her they gained by sacrifice Trasadasyu, a demi-god, like Indra, conquering foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The spouse of Purukutsa gave oblations to you, O Indra-Varuṇa, with homage. Then unto her ye gave King Trasadasyu, the demi-god, the slayer of the foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we, possessing much, delight in riches, Gods in oblations and the kine in pasture; And that Milch-cow who shrinks not from the milking, O Indra-Varuṇa, give to us daily. Next: HYMN XLIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHO will hear, who of those who merit worship, which of all Gods take pleasure in our homage? On whose heart shall we lay this laud celestial, rich with fair offerings, dearest to Immortals?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who will be gracious? Who will come most quickly of all the Gods? Who will bring bliss most largely? What car do they call swift with rapid coursers? That which the Daughter of the Sun elected.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So many days do ye come swiftly hither, as Indra to give help in stress of battle. Descended from the sky, divine, strong-pinioned, by which of all your powers are ye most mighty?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is the prayer that we should bring you, Aśvins, whereby ye come to us when invocated? Whether of you confronts e’en great betrayal? Lovers of sweetness, Dasras, help and save us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the wide space your chariot reacheth heaven, what time it turneth hither from the ocean. Sweets from your sweet shall drop, lovers of sweetness! These have they dressed for you as dainty viands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Sindhu with his wave bedew your horses: in fiery glow have the red birds come hither. Observed of all was that your rapid going, whereby ye were the Lords of Sūrya's Daughter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whene’er I gratified you here together, your grace was given us, O ye rich in booty. Protect, ye Twain, the singer of your praises: to you, Nāsatyas, is my wish directed. Next: HYMN XLIV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE will invoke this day your car, far-spreading, O Aśvins, even the gathering, of the sunlight,— Car praised in hymns, most ample, rich in treasure, fitted with seats, the car that beareth Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, ye gained that glory by your Godhead, ye Sons of Heaven, by your own might and power. Food followeth close upon your bright appearing when stately horses in your chariot draw you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who bringeth you to-day for help with offered oblation, or with hymns to drink the juices? Who, for the sacrifice's ancient lover, turneth you hither, Aśvins, offering homage?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne on your golden car, ye omnipresent! come to this sacrifice of ours, Nāsatyas. Drink of the pleasant liquor of the Soma give riches to the people who adore you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hitherward to us from earth, from heaven, borne on your golden chariot rolling lightly. Suffer not other worshippers to stay you here are ye bound by earlier bonds of friendship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now for us both, mete out, O Wonder-Workers, riches exceeding great with store of heroes, Because the men have sent you praise, O Aśvins, and Ajamīlhas come to the laudation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whene’er I gratified you here together, your grace was given us, O ye rich in booty. Protect, ye Twain, the singer of your praises: to you, Nāsatyas, is my wish directed. Next: HYMN XLV. Aśvins

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YONDER goes up that light: your chariot is yoked that travels round upon the summit of this heaven. Within this car are stored three kindred shares of food, and a skin filled with meath is rustling as the fourth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forth come your viands rich with store of pleasant meath, and cars and horses at the flushing of the dawn, Stripping the covering from the surrounded gloom, and spreading through mid-air bright radiance like the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink of the meath with lips accustomed to the draught; harness for the meath's sake the chariot that ye love. Refresh the way ye go, refresh the paths with meath: hither, O Aśvins, bring the skin that holds the meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The swans ye have are friendly, rich in store of meath, gold-pinioned, strong to draw, awake at early morn, Swimming the flood, exultant, fain for draughts that cheer: ye come like flies to our libations of the meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well knowing solemn rites and rich in meath, the fires sing to the morning Aśvins at the break of day, When with pure hands the prudent energetic priest hath with the stones pressed out the Soma rich in meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The rays advancing nigh, chasing with day the gloom, spread through the firmament bright radiance like the Sun; And the Sun harnessing his horses goeth forth: ye through your Godlike nature let his paths be known.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Devout in thought I have declared, O Aśvins, your chariot with good steeds, which lasts for ever, Wherewith ye travel swiftly through the regions to the prompt worshipper who brings oblation. Next: HYMN XLVI. Vāyu. Indra-Vāyu

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DRINK the best draught of Soma-juice, O Vāyu, at our holy rites: For thou art he who drinketh first.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, team-drawn, with thy hundred helps, with Indra, seated in the car, Vāyu, and drink your fill of juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May steeds a thousand bring you both, Indra. and Vāyu, hitherward To drink the Soma, to the feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For ye, O Indra-Vāyu, mount the golden-seated car that aids The sacrifice, that reaches heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On far-refulgent chariot come unto the man who offers gifts: Come, Indra-Vāyu, hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Indra-Vāyu, is the juice: drink it, accordant with the Gods, Within the giver's dwelling-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O Indra-Vāyu, be your journey here unyoke your steeds, Here for your draught of Soma juice. Next: HYMN XLVIL Vāyu. Indra-Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vāyu, the bright is offered thee, best of the meath at holy rites. Come thou to drink the Soma juice, God, longed-for, on thy team-drawn car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vāyu, thou and Indra are meet drinkers of these Soma-draughts, For unto you the drops proceed as waters gather to the vale.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Vāyu, mighty Twain, speeding together, Lords of Strength, Come to our succour with your team, that ye may drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The longed-for teams which ye possess, O Heroes, for the worshipper, Turn to us, Indra-Vāyu, ye to whom the sacrifice is paid. Next: HYMN XLVIII. Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: TASTE offerings never tasted yet, as bards enjoy the foeman's wealth. O Vāyu, on refulgent car come to the drinking of the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Removing curses, drawn by teams, with Indra, seated by thy side, O Vāyu, on refulgent car come to the drinking of the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The two dark treasuries of wealth that wear all beauties wait on thee. O Vāyu, on refulgent car come to the drinking of the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May nine-and-ninety harnessed steeds who yoke them at thy will bring thee. O Vāyu, on refulgent car come to the drinking of the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Harness, O Vāyu, to thy car a hundred well-fed tawny steeds, Yea, or a thousand steeds, and let thy chariot come to us with might. Next: HYMN XLIX. Indra-Bṛhaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DEAR is this offering in your mouth, O Indra and Bṛhaspati: Famed is the laud, the gladdening draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This lovely Soma is effused, O Indra and Bṛhaspati, For you, to drink it and rejoice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Soma-drinkers to our house come, Indra and Bṛhaspati-and Indra-to drink Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vouchsafe us riches hundredfold, O Indra, and Bṛhaspati, With store of horses, thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra. and Bṛhaspati, we call you when the meath is shed, With songs, to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink, Indra and Bṛhaspati, the Soma in the giver's house: Delight yourselves abiding there. Next: HYMN L. Bṛhaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who with might hath propped earth's ends, who sitteth in threefold seat, Bṛhaspati, with thunder, Him of the pleasant tongue have ancient sages, deep-thinking, holy singers, set before them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wild in their course, in well-marked wise rejoicing were they, Bṛhaspati, who pressed around us. Preserve Bṛhaspati, the stall uninjured, this company's raining, ever-moving birthplace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bṛhaspati, from thy remotest distance have they sat down who love the law eternal. For thee were dug wells springing from the mountain, which murmuring round about pour streams of sweetness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bṛhaspati, when first he had his being from mighty splendour in supremest heaven, Strong, with his sevenfold mouth, with noise of thunder, with his seven rays, blew and dispersed the darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With the loud-shouting band who sang his praises, with thunder, he destroyed obstructive Vala. Bṛhaspati thundering drave forth the cattle, the lowing cows who make oblations ready.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Serve we with sacrifices, gifts, and homage even thus the Steer of all the Gods, the Father. Bṛhaspati, may we be lords of riches, with noble progeny and store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Surely that King by power and might heroic hath made him lord of all his foes' posses-ions, Who cherishes Bṛhaspati well-tended, adorns and worships him as foremost sharer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In his own house he dwells in peace and comfort: to him for ever holy food flows richly. To him the people with free will pay homage-the King with whom the Brahman hath precedence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, unopposed, is master of the riches of his own subjects and of hostile people. The Gods uphold that King with their protection who helps the Brahman when he seeks his favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, Bṛhaspati, rainers of treasure, rejoicing at this sacrifice drink the Soma. Let the abundant drops sink deep within you: vouchsafe us riches with full store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bṛhaspati and Indra, make us prosper may this be your benevolence to us-ward. Assist our holy thoughts, wake up our spirit: weaken the hatred of our foe and rivals. Next: HYMN LI. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FORTH from the darkness in the region eastward this most abundant splendid light hatb mounted. Now verily the far-refulgent Mornings, Daughters of Heaven, bring welfare to the people.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The richly-coloured Dawns have mounted eastward, like pillars planted at our sacrifices, And, flushing far, splendid and purifying, unbarred the portals of the fold of darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dispelling gloom this day the wealthy Mornings urge liberal givers to present their treasures. In the unlightened depth of darkness round them let niggard traffickers sleep unawakened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Goddesses, is this your car, I ask you, ancient this day, or is it new, ye Mornings, Wherewith, rich Dawns, ye seek with wealth Navagva, Daśagva Aṅgira, the seven-toned singer?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With horses harnessed by eternal Order, Goddesses, swiftly round the worlds ye travel, Arousing from their rest, O Dawns, the sleeping, and all that lives, man, bird, and beast, to motion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Which among these is eldest, and where is she through whom they fixed the Ṛbhus' regulations? What time the splendid Dawns go forth for splendour, they are not known apart, alike, unwasting.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blest were these Dawns of old, shining with succour, true with the truth that springs from holy Order; With whom the toiling worshipper, by praises, hymning and lauding, soon attained to riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither from eastward all at once they travel, from one place spreading in the selfsame manner. Awaking, from the seat of holy Order the Godlike Dawns come nigh like troops of cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus they go forth with undiminished colours, these Mornings similar, in self-same fashion, Concealing the gigantic might of darkness with radiant bodies bright and pure and shining.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Goddesses, O Heaven's refulgent Daughters, bestow upon us wealth with store of children. As from our pleasant place of rest ye rouse us may we be masters of heroic vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well-skilled in lore of sacrifice, ye Daughters of Heaven, refulgent Dawns, I thus address you. May we be glorious among the people. May Heaven vouchsafe us this, and Earth the Goddess, Next: HYMN LII. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS Lady, giver of delight, after her Sister shining forth, Daughter of Heaven, hath shown herself.-

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unfailing, Mother of the Kine, in colour like a bright red mare, The Dawn became the Aśvins' Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, and thou art the Aśvins' Friend, the Mother of the Kine art thou: O Dawn thou rulest over wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thinking of thee, O joyous One, as her who driveth hate away, We woke to meet thee with our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our eyes behold thy blessed rays like troops of cattle loosed to feed. Dawn hath filled full the wide expanse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou hast filled it, Fulgent One! thou layest bare the gloom with light. After thy nature aid us, Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou overspreadest heaven with rays, the dear wide region of mid-air. With thy bright shining lustre, Dawn. Next: HYMN LIII. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: OF Savitar the God, the sapient Asura, we crave this great gift which is worthy of our choice, Wherewith he freely grants his worshiper defence. This with his rays the Great God hath vouchsafed to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sustainer of the heaven, Lord of the whole world's life, the Sage, he putteth on his golden-coloured mail. Clear-sighted, spreading far, filling the spacious realm, Savitar hath brought forth bliss that deserveth laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath filled full the regions of the heaven and earth: the God for his own strengthening waketh up the hymn. Savitar hath stretched out his arms to cherish life, producing with his rays and lulling all that moves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lighting all living creatures, ne’er to be deceived, Savitar, God, protects each holy ordinance. He hath stretched out his arms to all the folk of earth, and, with his laws observed, rules his own mighty course.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Savitar thrice surrounding with his mightiness mid-air, three regions, and the triple sphere of light, Sets the three heavens in motion and the threefold earth, and willingly protects us with his triple law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most gracious God, who brings to life and lulls to rest, he who controls the world, what moves not and what moves, May he vouchsafe us shelter,—Savitar the God,—for tranquil life, with triple bar against distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With the year's seasons hath Savitar, God, come nigh: may he prosper our home, give food and noble sons. May he invigorate us through the days and nights, and may he send us opulence with progeny. Next: HYMN LIV. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now must we praise and honour Savitar the God: at this time of the day the men must call to him, Him who distributes wealth to Manu's progeny, that he may grant us here riches most excellent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou at first producest for the holy Gods the noblest of all portions, immortality: Thereafter as a gift to men, O Savitar, thou openest existence, life succeeding life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If we, men as we are, have sinned against the Gods through want of thought, in weakness, or through insolence, Absolve us from the guilt and make us free from sin, O Savitar, alike among both Gods and men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None may impede that power of Savitar the God whereby he will maintain the universal world. What the fair-fingered God brings forth on earth's expanse or in the height of heaven, that work of his stands sure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To lofty hills thou sendest those whom Indra leads, and givest fixed abodes with houses unto these. However they may fly and draw themselves apart, still, Savitar, they stand obeying thy behest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the libations poured to thee thrice daily, day after day, O Savitar, bring us blessing. May Indra, Heaven, Earth, Sindhu with the Waters, Aditi with Ādityas, give us shelter. Next: HYMN LV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHO of you, Vasus, saveth? who protecteth? O Heaven and Earth and Aditi, preserve us, Varuṇa., Mitra, from the stronger mortal. Gods, which of you at sacrifice giveth comfort?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who with laud extol the ancient statutes, when they shine forth infallible dividers, Have ordered as perpetual Ordainers, and beamed as holy-thoughted Wonder-Workers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Housewife Goddess, Aditi, and Sindhu, the Goddess Svasti I implore for friendship: And may the unobstructed Night and Morning both, day and night, provide for our protection.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aryaman, Varuṇa have disclosed the pathway, Agni as Lord of Strength the road to welfare. Lauded in manly mode may Indra-Viṣṇu grant us their powerful defence and shelter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I have besought the favour of the Maruts, of Parvata, of Bhaga God who rescues. From trouble caused by man the Lord preserve us; from woe sent by his friend let Mitra save us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agree, through these our watery oblations, Goddesses, Heaven and Earth, with Ahibudhnya. As if to win the sea, the Gharma-heaters have opened, as they come anear, the rivers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Goddess Aditi with Gods defend us, save us the saviour God with care unceasing. We dare not stint the sacred food of Mitra and Varuṇa upon the back of Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is Sovran Lord of wealth, Agni of great prosperity: May he bestow these gifts on us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither to us, rich pleasant Dawn, bring many things to be desired, Thou who hast ample store of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So then may Bhaga, Savitar, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, Indra, with bounty come to us. Next: HYMN LVI. Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY mighty Heaven and Earth, most meet for honour, be present here with light and gleaming splendours; When, fixing them apart, vast, most extensive, the Steer roars loudly in far-reaching courses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Goddesses with Gods, holy with holy, the Two stand pouring out their rain, exhaustless: Faithful and guileless, having Gods for children, leaders of sacrifice with shining splendours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sure in the worlds he was a skilful Craftsman, he who produced these Twain the Earth and Heaven. Wise, with his power he brought both realms, together spacious and deep, well-fashioned, unsupported.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Heaven and Earth, with one accord promoting, with high protection as of Queens, our welfare, Far-reaching, universal, holy, guard us. May we, car-borne, through song be victors ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To both of you, O Heaven and Earth, we bring our lofty song of praise, Pure Ones! to glorify you both.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye sanctify each other's form, by your own proper might ye rule, And from of old observe the Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Furthering and fulfilling, ye, O Mighty, perfect Mitra's Law. Ye sit around our sacrifice. Next: HYMN LVII. Ksetrapati, Etc.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE through the Master of the Field, even as through a friend, obtain What nourisheth our kine and steeds. In such may he be good to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As the cow yieldeth milk, pour for us freely, Lord of the Field, the wave that beareth sweetness, Distilling meath, well-purified like butter, and let the. Lords of holy Law be gracious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet be the plants for us. the heavens, the waters, and full of sweets for us be air's mid-region. May the Field's Lord for us be full of sweetness, and may we follow after him uninjured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Happily work our steers and men, may the plough furrow happily. Happily be the traces bound; happily may he ply the goad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śuna and Sīra, welcome ye this laud, and with the milk which ye have made in heaven Bedew ye both this earth of ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Auspicious Sītā, come thou near: we venerate and worship thee That thou mayst bless and prosper us and bring us fruits abundantly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra press the furrow down, may Pūṣan guide its course aright. May she, as rich in milk, be drained for us through each succeeding year.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Happily let the shares turn up the plough-land, happily go the ploughers with the oxen. With meath and milk Parjanya make us happy. Grant us prosperity, Śuna and Sīra. Next: HYMN LVIII. Ghṛta.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FORTH from the ocean sprang the wave of sweetness: together with the stalk it turned to Amṛta, That which is holy oil's mysterious title: but the Gods’ tongue is truly Amṛta's centre.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us declare aloud the name of Ghṛta, and at this sacrifice hold it up with homage. So let the Brahman hear the praise we utter. This hath the four-horned Buffalo emitted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Four are his horns, three are the feet that bear him; his heads are two, his hands are seven in number. Bound with a triple bond the Steer roars loudly: the mighty God hath entered in to mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That oil in triple shape the Gods discovered laid down within the Cow, concealed by Paṇis. Indra produced one shape, Sūrya another: by their own power they formed the third from Vena.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From inmost reservoir in countless channels flow down these rivers which the foe beholds not. I look upon the streams of oil descending, and lo! the Golden Reed is there among them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like rivers our libations flow together, cleansing themselves in inmost heart and spirit. The streams of holy oil pour swiftly downward like the wild beasts that fly before the bowman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As rushing down the rapids of a river, flow swifter than the wind the vigorous currents, The streams of oil in swelling fluctuation like a red courser bursting through the fences.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like women at a gathering fair to look on and gently smiling, they incline to Agni. The streams of holy oil attain the fuel, and Jātavedas joyfully receives them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As maidens dock themselves with gay adornment to join the bridal feast, I now behold them. Where Soma flows and sacrifice is ready, thither the streams of holy oil are running.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send to our eulogy a herd of cattle bestow upon us excellent possessions. Bear to the Gods the sacrifice we offer the streams of oil flow pure and full of sweetness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The universe depends upon thy power and might within the sea, within the heart, within all life. Next: HYMN I. Agni
